segments.text: And now, from the University of Chicago Institute of Politics and CNN Audio, the
axe files with your host, David Axelrod.
Lori Lightfoot became mayor of Chicago.
One year ago this week, her tenure began with a acrimonious teacher strike and it's ended
with an epic pandemic.
I sat down with her last week to talk about this baptism of fire, where she thinks the
virus is going and how she plans to open up her city, plus her own remarkable story,
her journey from a small town in Ohio, the granddaughter of a sharecropper, to become
a prosecutor and ultimately a big city mayor.
And we talked about her status as America's first gay woman of color to lead a major American
city.
And here's that conversation.
Mayor, how are you?
I'm doing well on you.
Good.
Good to see you.
So next week, May 20th, one year in office, hell of a baptism you've had here.
I mean, you couldn't have imagined when you took that oath of office in Millennium Park
a year ago that this is how you'd be marking your first anniversary in office.
How are you personally holding up?
What is the emotional toll associated with having a lead a city through this kind of
catastrophe?
Well, I mean, as you might imagine, it ebbs and it flows.
My personality is one where I don't get too high and I don't get too low.
But certainly, you know, there are times when I feel like I've reached max in capacity.
So I try to take some time for myself every day.
Usually, it's early in the morning.
I'm an early riser.
So I just kind of take some time to kind of slowly move into the day, kind of set myself
emotionally.
And then I definitely do it every night before I go to bed.
Sometimes I'm so tired I don't need to.
I just fall asleep.
There's an expression in the church that I grew up in about laying your burdens down.
So what I try to do every night is just kind of let the burdens of the day to the side
because they're going to be there the next day.
I don't need to wrestle with them all night long.
You know, easier said than done, of course.
Yeah, that's a great quality.
I need to take some lessons from you on that.
I've never quite mastered that.
But that is, it's important.
How's your family doing you and your wife, Amy, have a 12-year-old Vivian?
12-year-olds are not necessarily all that keen on being penned up inside.
How's she doing?
She's doing fine.
You know, she starts her day off every morning with a Zoom conference call from her teacher
with her classmates.
So when I'm running out the door in the morning, she's engaged in whatever the day's events
are.
And then I come home at night and she is discovered Fortnite.
So that's like the daily obsession between her and varying groups of friends.
But you know, it's hard.
I mean, this would be a time where she'd be out running track.
She's an athletic kid.
She missed a lot of her basketball season because she had a broken leg.
And so it was very looking forward to track and then COVID hits.
So we tried to kind of get that as much exercise as we can.
We're fortunate enough to have a yard, so we do that.
But it's not the same.
And it's not the same of being with your classmates every day and that kind of intimacy, that
close proximity builds.
But these are kids that have grown up in the digital age with all these devices.
So it's probably a little bit different than when you and I were growing up.
Speaking of the digital age, you've become quite the sensation online here.
You're a viral sensation.
You've been doing, you know, you've done all these videos about how to occupy yourself
at home.
You've done, I guess, parody of singing, you're baking.
You've done a lot of some crazy things that have really caught on with people.
How have you eased into the role of a viral star?
Well, you know, I don't pay a lot of attention personally to social media, but I've got a
great creative team.
And when the memes started kind of popping up and having me all over Chicago, you know,
we wanted to kind of bring home this message of staying home to save lives.
We've done it in a parody of that, a take off around the senses.
So you know, look, we're trying to meet people where they are.
These memes caught fire.
They kind of originated organically.
And so we row the wave that somebody else really started.
Now does Vivian catch you on TikTok in those places?
So here's Vivian's reaction.
She's obsessed with TikTok.
And she's been trying to get Amy and I to do a TikTok with her.
And I'm like, no, I'm not doing that.
So when I came home that night and said, by the way, I just did my first TikTok.
Of course, her reaction was, I can't believe you did it with somebody else and you did
not do it with me.
So such is such is a life of a 12 year old.
Yes, I remember that.
I remember that period.
Listen, you know, I was a city hall reporter when Harold Washington got elected mayor
of Chicago.
You were the second elected African American mayor of Chicago.
One of the striking things about this pandemic is just how brutal it has been on communities
of color, those fault lines that you talked about during your campaign that you've talked
about since they've been exposed in just a really tragic way.
75% of the cases in Chicago reported cases have been in the black and Hispanic communities.
Deaths half the deaths in Chicago among the African American community, which is only 30%
of the population.
How do you process that?
And what do we do about it?
How do we begin to deal with the things that led up to this kind of tragedy?
Well, it's an enormous challenge.
And for me personally, processing those realities, it's been hard.
When I first heard the data around African American, the impact on the African American
community, I immediately went to thinking about my mother.
Now, she doesn't live here, but she's 91 years old and has underlying conditions.
I'm the youngest of four and my siblings are old enough that they fit into the demographic
of over 60 and several have underlying conditions.
So it's hard not to feel that personally.
But what I also knew is it was really important for us not to just drop this information on
people, but as you said, to really come up with some concrete ways in which we as a
city and then embracing our community partners could really respond to this because there
is a need.
I mean, it's not a secret that there are healthcare disparities in our city.
It's not a secret that way too many people live in poverty and that black and brown communities
are have much higher rate of these underlying conditions that we now know are the death
male for COVID.
You know, 93% or higher than that of the people who have died had underlying medical conditions
like diabetes, heart disease, upper respiratory disease.
So that is a haunting statistic.
And I think the way that I process it is to feel like we are doing something to address
that we are empowering people by giving them information, that we are connecting them up
to healthcare systems, whether it's a family doctor or a federally qualified health center,
that we are being as responsive and close to the ground in these neighborhoods that
are so dramatically affected and being empathetic and making sure that we are doing everything
we can to flood those areas with resources.
You know what worries me is that when this goes, when this lifts, whenever that is and
God knows we all hope that it's sooner rather than later, that those same conditions will
exist that made these communities vulnerable.
You've talked a lot about and you've laid out ambitious visions and plans for trying
to eradicate poverty in the city and getting into these neighborhoods that are most vulnerable
right now.
It's also true that this virus is also eating away at cities' revenues, creating extraordinary
budget concerns for you.
And you already had a situation where you have pension obligations that are growing, that
you're now responsible to deal with.
The history of this is that when these things happen, the first communities that suffer
are the communities that always suffer, the poor, the vulnerable.
How do you launch a war on poverty when you are in such a financial bind?
I think we have no choice.
I gave a speech last December to the Economic Club and then I spoke with them yesterday.
At the time in December, I said that we can't be a great global city unless we focus on
inclusive growth, that we see the city as being something larger and bigger than the
central business district.
I repeated that message yesterday.
While yes, these problems are tough.
They were daunting before COVID.
They're even more daunting now.
But the thing that we've been doing all along and I've really pushed my staff is to
not build temporary staff scaffolding.
We don't want to put a band-aid on a gaping wound.
We're not going to solve the problem in this entirely in the months and the arc of this
virus, but we've got to accelerate the plans that we previously had and start to address
these long-standing problems now.
And that's precisely what we've done.
And then thinking about the budget and the impact of this is significant.
There's no question about it.
I am grateful for the money that we've gotten from the federal government and I've got to
give credit to the Democrats in the House because we would have gotten a lot less, but
but for the leadership of the speaker and others to insist upon direct aid to cities
like Chicago, I'm hopeful that they'll win more because the CARES Act money that we
received already is constrained.
We can only use that for COVID responses.
And believe me, we're going to use it because we're going to need it, but we need more support,
but we have to continue to speak our values even in these tough economic times.
If we shed and move away from those communities that are most in need right now, we're giving
up on a huge swass of Chicago.
We're saying that Chicago is not going to be 2.7 million.
It's barely going to be 2 million because people will leave.
Right.
And most of the people who are leaving are people of color, poor people.
Chicago is really one of the only world-class cities where you see population declining,
and that's where the decline is happening.
That's exactly right.
And if we give up and say we can't afford to do the kind of investments that we can't
afford to have inclusive economic growth, we're giving up on a vision of Chicago.
That I just think is critically important to define who we are now and in the future.
I totally get that.
I just don't know where the money comes from.
Some of it may be from the voluntary contributions of those people you were talking to yesterday
at the Economic Club.
And the question is, how much are they willing to put their money where your mouth is and
try and deal with some of these problems?
Because it seems impossible that you can get the money you need simply from taxpayers'
property taxes are high already.
Yeah, there's no question.
We never envisioned that we were going to have the city of Chicago go at a long strategy.
We have to have partnership.
Both partnerships in helping us think about what the policy prescriptions should be.
But of course, partnerships in terms of the money and the revenue.
And we've been very fortunate already when we announced, for example, our Invest Southwest
program, which is investing in exactly the same neighborhoods.
We put up money from the city, but we were joined by BMO Harris Bank.
They put up $20 million.
And then we got another 10 from Starbucks and on and on.
We can't do these things and move the needle in an meaningful way without partnerships
of the philanthropy community, but also the business community.
I've always thought that to deal with the massive problems that go into the situation
that these communities are in would require a massive response from the philanthropic community,
the corporate community.
Governments simply doesn't have the resources to do everything that's necessary.
Listen, in addition to making people laugh, you've also scared the hell out of people.
And you've been out on the street at times when there were people who were defying the
stay-at-home order, including young people partying.
And you've been very blunt about your feelings about that.
Now we're reaching something of a breaking point with some people who've been inside
for a long time.
It was a predictable that as time went on, people would be impatient.
A lot of people out of work.
A lot of small businesses.
I know you've spoken to that at the breaking point.
And yet we're not nearly done.
The virus is still out there.
There's no vaccine yet.
So are you worried about that?
Are you worried about just more and more defiance, more and more resistance, lack of political
will to do what's necessary?
And then finding us, as Dr. Bright, who testified before Congress today, warned, finding us
back in a situation that is as bad or worse a few months from now.
So those are all the things that we worry about and talk about on a daily basis and really
multiple times a day.
We, as humans, and I think certainly as Americans, take our physical liberty very seriously.
And we like to gather in groups.
And our city is really built around having fun, recreational and entertainment options.
That's one of the things that makes Chicago special.
And as the weather gets warm and while we didn't have the terrible winter that we've
had in many years, your body and I think your mind has an expectation that when a days get
longer, when the sun is shining, it's time to be outside.
It's time to reconvene with people that you may not have seen during the winter months.
So we have to manage that and deal with that reality.
And so I've been reading a lot, as has our Department of Public Health, about how we
can safely convene, particularly outside.
And I think there's opportunities for us to not move away from the diligence about social
distancing.
That's going to be what that's, I think, for the foreseeable future.
I do think that there's a way in which we can gather outside safely with limitations,
certainly mask, certainly hand sanitizers, smaller groups, but listen to music.
See a play.
You know, all the kind of things that we would ordinarily do inside, some of what we do
outside.
I think there are ways, given the great venues that we have, to bring those experiences
outside.
I do think that that is possible.
President has been sort of encouraging that spirit of resistance lately.
I know you've had an interesting relationship.
He called you when you were elected.
You had a nice conversation.
I think Ivanka Trump called you and you met with her.
It's been a little less friendly at times since then.
But how would you weigh what he's doing right now and his insistence that things open?
And it seems in contravention of some of the advice he's getting from his own public
health people.
But look, I mean, I really don't spend a lot of time thinking about Donald Trump.
He would be disappointed to hear you say that.
I just don't.
Because I don't really think that in this time in the daily press briefings that he's
offered things that are really helpful and constructive for me as a leader or really
for people, residents of Chicago.
And in many instances, and there's been a lot of reporting on it, of course, he said
things that are just downright dangerous and dumb.
So I don't spend a lot of time kind of trying to unravel the psyche of Donald Trump on daily
basis.
Is he making it harder though for you and other mayors and governors?
There's no doubt.
There's no doubt that he's making it harder.
But he's making it harder mostly because the federal response has been so halting.
And it's been that way really from the very beginning of this pandemic.
It was too slow.
It wasn't a plan.
They weren't bringing us into a lot of the early things that were necessary that they
were dictating that had to be operationalized at the local level, particularly around airports
and screening and a lot of that.
We're on the ground here.
We have to take responsibility for that.
And they weren't talking to us.
And it was very clear that they didn't have a plan.
More recently, and we've been in a well-position with things like PPEs and Vents because our
public health department really prepares our year-long.
But the one thing that we absolutely need to have some uniformity on is testing.
We need the physical test kits to be able to make sure that we can open safely.
And the fact that literally it's every man or woman for themselves is a terrible indictment
of the federal response.
But also, it makes it really difficult for us to cogently be able to tell our residents
that they're safe because we're scrambling literally every single day following every
lead to have a small handful of tests that we can put into a community center or a federally
qualified health center or pushing our labs and our hospitals to ramp up their testing
capabilities.
It's this scramble and adjective that's been developed because of the void left by the
federal government.
Well, you also told people on Monday, Mayor, that everybody who wants a test can get one.
Well, he said that before, and we know that's not true.
It's just simply not true.
Now, everybody who's named Donald Trump that wants a test can get one.
But that's not true for you or me.
We're going to take a short break, and we'll be right back with more of the axe files.
You talked about people seeing a play, maybe hearing some music outdoors.
One of the things that you did that got quite a bit of attention, you did it early, was
you shut down the lakefront, which is, of course, the front yard of Chicago.
That's where people do gather.
Do you expect to open that up soon?
I wouldn't say soon, but we are working on plans to be able to open up the lakefront.
Look, I get it.
I love the lake.
There's nothing more calming to me than taking a drive on Lakeshore Drive, finding that little
secret spot, which I won't reveal, that I go to just to watch the water and the waves.
I mean, it's cathartic, and I get it.
But what I go back to, what led me to close it, and we had done a lot of education around
social gathering, the danger of clustering in two larger groups.
We talked over and over and over again, and people just flat out, ignored the guidance.
What I want to do is, when we reopen the lakefront, and we will, we do it in a way that's smart,
and that, unfortunately, in many of these things, we have to play to the lowest common
denominator.
The person who's just not going to pay attention, what do we do to make sure that we can keep
that person safe and minimize the risk that they're going to pose to other people?
So I've gotten a lot of very interesting suggestions from residents.
We're working with a lot of the lakefront aldermen on a plan.
We'll get there, but we're just not ready yet.
That's one of the things that worries me about the president telling people that things are
getting better, that this is going to go away on its own, that we've got to reopen because
it sends a signal that isn't consonant with the situation we're facing.
He also said was critical of Dr. Fauci for raising cautionary notes that schools should
open in the fall.
What about Chicago schools?
Are you confident that schools will be, public schools will be open and students attending
them with their physical presence in the fall?
Well, you know, I'll play lawyer and say define confidence.
I can't look into a crystal ball and say where we're going to be.
That's your old life, you can't do that.
Yeah.
Yeah, my law department tells me that every day.
Look, my ambition is to get our kids back in school this fall.
We have done, I think, Yeoman's work on remote learning, but the reality is we have a huge
digital divide in various parts of our city that affects our young people's ability to
connect up with the internet, Wi-Fi access, and we will end up spending multiple tens
of millions of dollars to address that issue.
And we got to address it because it's a larger problem.
But what I also know is I think about the little kids when my daughter was a three-year-old
going to pre-K.
The social-emotional learning that happens in that environment, when they're away from
their parents for the first time and they're with other kids and they're with their teachers
and they start to learn the love of learning, structure of school, being able to play safely.
All of those things are critically important, particularly for our youngest kids, and that
doesn't happen when you're seeing your teacher for the very first time ever on a digital
screen.
So for those kids, when I think about it, it's really important that we get them back
in school.
Now again, we're not going to do it in a way that puts anybody at risk.
We're not going to do it in a way that isn't consultative with the entire ecosystem of
those school environment.
The principals, the teachers, the aides, the lunchroom staff, all of those people are important
for the lifeblood of a school.
And we've got to do it in a way that we keep them safe and we keep the children safe.
But absolutely, I have an ambition that if we keep trending in the right direction, we
want to get our kids back in school.
And it may not be full-time, 30 kids in the classroom.
That's probably not smart.
We can do it in lots of different ways.
We can spread out the spaces because there's lots of different spaces that are available
in schools where we can hold classes.
They're going to be remote learning that's done, I think, at the city college's level.
Maybe we would purpose some of those spaces.
I think the way in which we can think creatively about how to bring our children back with
their teachers, there's no limit to that.
And we've got to explore every opportunity because of how important it is for those youngest
of children to find that connection with their beloved teachers.
So ambition but no guarantee, basically.
We can't...
There's no way anybody who can guarantee what's going to happen in the fall is making it
up.
There's no guarantee they can be given.
So you are a big sports fan.
You've been a Bears ticket season holder for 20 years.
Everybody wants to know if there's going to be sports in the foreseeable future and
if that sports will involve actually fans, you and others sitting in their seats watching
the game tour, are they going to be consigned to watching it on TV until there's a vaccine
or a significant treatment for this?
Well, first again, we've got to be guided by the data.
And the Sports League executives that I've talked to, of course, are thinking about how
do they get their players back in the field for the obvious reasons.
Their most valuable asset, of course, are the players.
And they all, every single one of those professional sports teams, has really strong, robust unions.
So I have confidence that there will be a meeting of the minds about what makes sense.
If I had to protect right now, again, looking into my non-existent crystal ball, I do think
that sports will start.
There could be some delay, but I don't think they're going to start with fans in the stadiums
in the first instance.
I just don't see that as a possibility.
You, I ask you that question as the former star point guard for Washington High School
in Masaland, Ohio.
And I wanted to talk to you mentioned, I want to talk a little bit about your story, which
is a remarkable story.
You mentioned your mom, and I'm sure when you say you think of her, it's not just that
she's 91 and vulnerable.
She also spent a lot of her life working in nursing homes as a home health care worker.
And so, and she would have been on the front line right now.
She would have been one of those people who's more exposed than others because she was out
there helping people.
No, I think a lot about that as I talk to health care workers, as I talk to the unions
who are concerned, and also just the folks that run these facilities.
I know from my mom's experience, and I hope to, I hope to God is a million times better
than it was when she was out there.
They are in the front lines.
They don't get the training that they should get.
And they don't oftentimes get the kind of equipment to keep them safe.
I think it's a different world now, and part of that is because many of these workers
are unionized.
But we know that there are still other workers, mostly women of color, who are in a care community,
who are taking care of seniors.
You know, at the end of my mother's work life, she took care of people who were sick
and shut in, made them meals, bathed them, and just kept them company.
Those workers, they're invisible to many people.
And, and I worry a lot about them in particular.
Now, we also know from the archivist virus that congregate settings are places where this
virus just spreads like wildfire.
That's why our Department of Public Health has been very active and engaged with senior
centers, nursing homes, and other settings like that.
Because it's so critically important that those places understand the data, have every
support possible, and that they are getting testing of their workers and the residents
who live there.
Absolutely.
Your folks, your father Elijah, he was the son of a sharecropper.
Both your parents grew up in the segregated South, moved north.
He had hearing loss as a result of men and chitis.
And you've talked about that and how he had to scuffle to make a living and deal with
his disabilities and so on.
Tell me about that and tell me about your, your dad.
My dad's been gone for 10 years and I miss him every day.
I have a picture of the two of us, beside my bed that I look at at night and I look at
it in the morning.
He had a very hard life.
And in some ways, I think he never recovered from growing up in the South.
And then adding proverbial insult to injury, growing up, not really having an opportunity
to live out his life's ambitions, getting sick, sir early on in his early 20s, losing
his hearing.
So being a black man with a high school education and then a profound disability, just really
shaped and confined his world.
My dad had a great sense of humor.
He had loved life, but he had to work hard every single day.
I talk a lot about my mother because I spent a lot of time with my mother as a kid because
my dad was working two and three jobs every day.
And just to, he worked his full time job and then he would come home and eat and then he
would go and do work at night.
And then on the weekends, he was a barber.
So he cut people's hair and he shined shoes.
That's when my dad in and Sundays were really the only day where I got to see my dad for
the entirety of the day because his work life was six days a week.
But he's a very, very different person than my mom.
And in some ways, very different than me.
I'm much more like her in terms of personality, but just a good, decent human being.
And I think a lot about him every day.
I see my father in the faces of men of color who are working their tails off to have some
dignity.
Sorry.
Not at all.
Not at all.
Not at all.
Do you, how much did his struggle forge your determination to do what you've done with
your own life?
It definitely deeply influenced me to see my father worrying every single day about
basics, the utilities, its car payment, rent.
And then we were fortunate enough to move into a house and have a mortgage.
I never wanted to struggle in the way that he did.
And I didn't know where my life would take me, but I knew that I wanted to have some
economic freedom at least so that I could help them, which I have done, but also be able
to help myself and have some freedom.
You know, when you have to worry every single day about staying in your house, about somebody
coming and taking your car, about just being able to get through the day financially,
that takes a toll on you.
And that was the story of my parents' life, for much of their married life together.
You mentioned that they were able to buy a house.
They moved to, yours was a segregated town like most towns were in the day's small industrial
kind of town, about 400 miles from Chicago in Ohio.
But they moved to a predominantly white neighborhood and they did that intentionally.
Talk to me about that and how did that impact on you?
Because you must have been very much in a minority in some of your school classes and
in your neighborhood and so on.
How did that shape your thinking and your life?
I think that, look, the town was incredibly segregated.
And at the time that my parents were making a decision about where they could buy, they
wanted to buy, well, we lived in this area for the entirety of my life.
We moved probably into a house that was about four or five blocks away from our rental home.
But they wanted us to be able to stay close to the friends that we had known our entire
growing up years and to be in the same school system that we had known.
So my parents really sacrificed everything for us as children.
And really, the way in which they lived their lives was about what was best for us.
And so that really drove the decisions.
And you're right, when I have a brother who was six years older than me, when he left my
elementary school for the entirety of the rest of the time that I was there, which is
about five years from first grade to sixth grade, I was literally the only black kid in
my school.
And in my town, it was black and white.
They were tiny, tiny, maybe two or three families that were Latinx.
So yeah, I grew up for most of my schooling until I got to high school as being either
the only or a small handful of black students in an otherwise white school.
And how did that feel?
I mean, was there, did you feel as an outsider there?
I mean, yes and no, right?
I grew up in the late sixties and early seventies.
You know, while it was Ohio, not Alabama, you know, segregation was still an issue,
blatant on the table, racial discrimination was still a thing.
There were certain things I couldn't do.
And I knew places I couldn't go because I was black that my classmates were going to.
And yeah, I mean, I definitely struggled with my identity as a black person for a long time
growing up in very white environment.
I think the thing that was helpful to me is I was a good student.
So I was always one of the best in my class, best in the school.
That made a huge difference.
And then when I was in seventh or eighth grade, my mother got appointed to the local school
board and then she ran for election and then through the rest of my time in school, she
was a member of the school board.
So frankly, that helped a lot.
But when I got to high school and then we were, it was one public high school in my
town, I started then seeing black kids, some of them who I knew from church, that a lot
of whom I didn't know.
And it was a struggle because I stood out like a sore thumb.
I talk like I talk now.
I didn't, as they said, talk black.
And there was a lot of you think you're better.
You know, a lot of the petty crap that happens in junior high and really in high school,
I experienced a lot of that.
But I had my mother in my ear constantly, literally and but also figuratively telling
me to push myself to do the best I could, not let people bring me down.
I mean, that was kind of a daily mantra in my household.
But yeah, it was tough.
It was absolutely tough.
One of your siblings, your brother Brian, took a different path and not a happy one.
And as I don't know what his status is now, but spent a lot of time in the criminal justice
system, how did that impact on you?
And it must have been terribly difficult for your parents.
It was really hard.
It was really hard on us as a family.
I told this story.
Yeah, for some people, and my brother was definitely one of them, the street life is
almost like an narcotic in and of itself.
It is incredibly alluring.
And my brother started kind of going in a different direction when he was a teenager.
I can remember when he was probably 13, 14 years old, hanging out with a group of guys,
some of whom beat him to jail, some of whom died.
He had a friend who was killed in a robbery when he was a teenager.
But my brother was determined to really take a very different course.
And he ended up spending most of his adult life locked up.
The last was 17 years in federal prison.
He got out now probably five or six years ago.
He lives now in the same town that my mother lives in.
But when you're a 60-something year old man and you've never really had a legitimate
job in your life, and you've spent the entirety of your growing up years on the inside, that
does something to you.
Are you in touch?
Kind of.
We go through ebbs and flows.
He came and he was here for the inauguration.
Our context is kind of slowly diminished over time.
My brother struggles with addiction still.
He's now 60-something years old.
He's got some physical challenges.
But not having any skill that's transferrable.
He'd love to be wearing a suit every day and being in office.
That's just not realistic when you've been a guy on the streets for most of your life.
And so the hustle is very still very alluring to him.
And now a word from our sponsors.
We'll be right back with more of the X-fons.
Later in your life you became a federal prosecutor.
And you prosecuted gangbangers and drug leaders and leaders of drug cartels.
How did the experience of having senior brother go through what he went through and
do the things he did in any way impact on your view as a prosecutor?
I mean it really did from the very beginning.
When I was going through the final stages of my background check as a federal prosecutor,
my brother was a fugitive.
I had to sign a allegiance form which still makes me angry.
I'll use that word.
That I was going to be loyal to the constitution and of all the laws because my brother was
a fugitive from justice.
Yeah, and of course like with seeing my father and the men in the eyes of really hard working
men of color.
I of course thought about my brother when I was prosecuting Chicago Street gang members.
And it made me want to know their stories and made me want to understand how they came
to choose the life that they chose.
And we had a range of interesting conversations with the young men that were both cooperators
but also the young men that we were arranging plea deals for.
Some of the men that I prosecuted here on the streets in Chicago ended up in a facility
in Myelin, Michigan when my brother was there at the same time.
So that made for interesting conversations with him and with my parents.
But look when you have a family member who is locked up, it has incredible impact, emotional
impact.
You can't, my brother was still locked up when my dad died and he didn't get to say
goodbye.
And I know that haunts him.
So there's nothing about the incarceration of human beings that is easy, that is simple,
even the people that are the most dangerous and that are psychopathic and some of them
are.
That's somebody's kid.
Yeah.
That's somebody's sibling.
And you can never forget that.
And I certainly never forgot that when I was a prosecutor.
You went to the University of Michigan and then you came here to the University of Chicago
Law School.
You arrived here just when Harold Washington was completing his first term running for
a very interesting dynamic kind of tumultuous time in Chicago politics.
I'm wondering what your memories of Harold were.
He was having worked for him, it covered him and then I worked for him by the time
you got here I was working for him.
Maybe one of the most charismatic figures that I've ever known in politics and I've
worked with a lot of people.
A remarkable guy.
Yeah.
So I remember him because when I was a junior in college, I took a semester and worked in
Washington and attended American University.
And I just by chance happened to be in a committee hearing as a young staffer when the announcement
came out that he had won.
And he was in Washington.
He's being congratulated by his colleagues.
So I was fascinated from him, of him from a distance and then fast forward several years
later.
I never knew him as a mayor or as a human being but he clearly was one of the most fascinating,
charismatic elected officials.
I think the city and maybe this country has ever seen.
And coming here in 86 when he was running for a reelection and seeing the machine in
all of its warts and glory and then understanding the excitement that he ignited, particularly
in Black Chicago and the kind of progressive lakefront liberals as they were calling those
days.
And I remember election day really, really well.
And I left in the morning and I planned a vote after I came home from class and I had
like 10 notes on my door saying, hey, you haven't voted.
Hey, you haven't voted.
Now that was not my experience and I thought, how the hell these people know I didn't vote
yet?
Because I didn't understand at that stage the dynamics.
But it was like nothing I'd ever seen.
And then I remember, I remember really clearly hearing the news that he had died.
Seven months or something after he got reelected.
Yeah, and the days after the how things were so tumultuous, I walked through the City
Hall lobby to view his body.
I was at UIC when that infamous rally was held and people were saying no deals, no deals
that already cut their deal.
To replace him, yes.
Yeah.
I remember them as clearly as you.
I was very much involved in that.
The great thing about that moment, the sad thing, it was unbelievably sad.
It was remarkable though how the City that was so divided when he first got elected,
so embraced him at the end.
And when you walk through those lines at City Hall, there were people white and black
from every neighborhood in the City who had come to embrace him as their leader.
And it was really a tremendous loss.
I can ask you something else about law school and it relates to the conversation we were
having earlier.
I asked you about how you adjusted to the racial identity issues when you were growing up.
You also came out when you were in law school.
And it made me wonder when did you embrace your own identity, your sexual identity?
How was that experience of deciding when it was time and how was that received by your
family?
Well, coming out at the University of Chicago Law School in 86, 87 was not the place that
I would have anticipated doing that.
You know the law school at that time.
It was hyper-conservative.
Yes.
There were very few people of color.
But interestingly, there were actually a lot of gays in the law school.
And that really helped me.
There were, you know, I have still to this day incredible friendships among a lot of
gay men and women that I met during that time.
And it really helped me see that I could be my authentic self.
I worried a lot about losing my parents.
My parents were really, you know, going to church, you know, every Sunday, every Wednesday,
and a couple other days in between conservatives.
I didn't know at the time, of course, I didn't know anybody gay that was growing up.
When I was growing up, and of course, with benefit of hindsight, I did.
And so I spent a lot of years worrying about losing my parents.
But something clicked over time in law school where I just felt like I'm not going to be
happy if I'm not who I am.
And to my parents' credit, when I told them, they couldn't have been more gracious.
They couldn't have been more lovely.
My father really, I think, was my mother didn't talk much about it because that's just what
she doesn't do.
She doesn't want to talk about something.
She just shuts it off and, you know, moves on.
But my father was lovely and couldn't have been more generous and embracing and loving.
You spent seven years in private practice.
And then, as we mentioned earlier, you became a prosecutor.
Why did you choose that direction?
Well, ironically, particularly given my brother's circumstance, I had always kind of been drawn
to law enforcement.
You know, I'm a rules girl.
I believe in justice.
And I thought about the FBI when I was in law school, but both because I was gay and
also at the time the FBI had a rule that you had to travel to a different, live in a different
city for five years.
I didn't want to do that.
So I just kind of put that ambition to the side.
But I liked the work I was doing at the firm, which increasingly became internal investigations
and criminal defense work.
And I worked with a number of federal prosecutors, former federal prosecutors who, you know,
suggested to me that if I was interested, I was not one of these, you know, law school
people who had this ambition.
My professional life was already charted out.
So I kind of fell into the opportunity.
But it was the best thing that I could have ever done.
Really taught me how to be a lawyer.
It taught me the power of being a prosecutor.
And by that, I mean, you do literally get to make decisions about people's liberty, who
gets charged, what they get charged with, how tough you go or not.
I mean, that is an awesome power that one can never underestimate.
And I got some grief to be sure from my more liberal friend saying, why do you want to
be the man?
Right?
What I wanted to be was somebody who sat at that table because of the power and to bring
my life experiences to those very nuanced, discretionary decisions that every prosecutor
holds in their hand.
It's a little bit of a different talent set or orientation than the office you have now.
Prosecutors are in many ways solitary figures.
They are responsive to the law and to judges.
But as you say, make a lot of decisions on their own.
You're in a position now where you have to build consensus in order to get things done.
Yes, you have to make decisions, but you can't make them all by yourself most of the time.
Has that been an adjustment for you?
Well, I would actually say that my experience as a prosecutor was very different than what
you describe.
First of all, it's an incredibly collegial place because you can't talk about what you
do every day with the world.
It's hard to have your spouse relate.
And I know this from having drug Amy to a lot of events where there are a bunch of former
prosecutors, she learned pretty quickly to say, no, no, I'm good.
You go on your own.
It is a unique collegial world.
And of course, you have discretion, but you're talking through these issues with your colleagues,
with your supervisor on a regular basis.
And so I learned a lot about collegiality from that experience.
And I hope that my style as mayor, both with my team, but also in embracing members of
the public is much more collegial because of that experience.
And what I know is that I'm very decisive.
I can get to a decision pretty quickly.
But the best decisions and the ones that are most valued are the ones where you bring people
along in the journey from the very beginning.
So I don't think that you do a plebiscite on every decision you can.
You'll be paralyzed, particularly in a time like this where literally every single day,
I'm making tens of, it's not hundreds of decisions, micro decisions every day and big decisions
every day.
But being able to have a sense of the pulse of people whose lives are going to be affected
by what you're doing, that's a good thing.
It makes things slower, but it's a better thing at the end.
I have to ask you, and this is a painful thing that you've spoken to, but you got rebuked
at one point by a federal judge, Richard Posner, who actually was associate with the
University of Chicago, because of your handling of one case.
And that thing stuck with you for a while.
I know you feel that that was unjust.
It was fundamentally unjust.
You know, look, it's too complicated to explain here, but I was a low man on a tonal pole
involving an international extradition.
As you might imagine, as a junior lawyer in the office, I didn't make those kind of
decisions on my own.
I made them with my supervisor.
But Posner, I think, frankly, got over his skis and wanted to hold the U.S. Attorney's
Office responsible.
And there were some other, I think, dynamics going on between the Seventh Circuit and the
office at the time.
And I got the short end of the proverbial stick.
I pride myself on my integrity.
I worry over, particularly when I was a lawyer, every word I wrote.
When I was signing my name on a pleading, I wanted to make sure that was something I
could be proud of and that I could defend.
And I never have ever, in 30-plus years of practice, departed from that.
Obviously, the Seventh Circuit saw it in a different way.
The thing that gives me then and now heart is I had people from every side of the V,
meaning prosecutors, defendants, judges, a whole host of people from the bar in Chicago
that stood up and say, I've worked with Lori Lightfoot.
I know who she is.
This is a person of integrity.
Luckily, Posner cited that and saying, well, the public rebuke is enough.
But if you've dealt with Posner, you know that he's undaunted by the facts many times.
I quickly have to cover some very big things.
One is you prosecuted political corruption cases in the city.
You prosecuted an alderman when you were there at the U.S. Attorney's Office.
You also prosecuted, as we mentioned, drug dealers, gangs.
On the political corruption issue, why is Chicago, I get this question a lot, why is
Chicago so subject to corruption?
Why has it been historically so?
And then the second one I get is why is it so subject to gang violence more so than other
cities?
We've had now several different looks at this and I'm wondering what your thoughts are.
Those are both great and big complicated questions.
On the public corruption, I think part of it is just because we've tolerated it too
long.
You know, others, I don't think Chicago historically is any more corrupt than other places, New
York, Philadelphia, LA, but the tolerance for it in those other places became less and
less over time.
In my experience in 30 plus years of living in the city, the tolerance for it is still
really great.
I'm probably, you probably didn't read the indictment of Ed Burke, but I did.
Ed Burke, the senior alderman in the city council, longtime power in the city in the
democratic organization, go ahead.
There's a lot of fascinating things about the indictment, but to me, one of the most
telling and I think response to your question is there's some dude from the, you know, the
buildings department that gets whistled to Ed Burke's ward office.
He stays there for five or ten minutes, clearly got a set of instructions and then dutifully
went and on some trumped up bases, shut down a building site because from the Ed Burke's
perspective, the guy hadn't come across with the money.
He hadn't hired him to do the legal work.
And so while this person probably didn't know there was a criminal conspiracy going
on, the obedience to this power and doing something that didn't comport at all, you know,
with a building called what is actual true job wise, but the willingness to be a party
to it because a powerful alderman and a staff had commanded it, we have just tolerated corruption
way too long.
And you know, gang violence is really complicated, but in short strokes, it comes down in my
mind to poverty.
It's the absence of, it's the absence of jobs, investments, money, good quality education,
you know, and you know, we're both experienced with USC.
What do they teach us?
People are rational economic actors.
When you have nothing and then there's this opportunity for something and when drug dealing
becomes the only form of economic activity that can get you money to take care of your
basic needs.
So our goal has to be obviously to lock up violent people and make the community safe,
but it has to be grounded in a strategy of supplanting that form of the economy with
another that's legitimate and gives people a pipeline for a lifetime.
Without question, I think that does not, I agree with that completely.
It doesn't completely explain why gangs have flourished in Chicago in such great numbers
in a way that they haven't in other cities, but that's a we could probably do a whole
hour on that.
Before I leave you, I have to ask you about policing and because you were chairman of the
Chicago police board, you were the chair of the policy accountability task force after
Laquan McDonald was killed here in Chicago, a nationally known case.
Now you're the mayor of the city and the police force works for you and you've been
a prosecutor and I guess my question to you is how do you find that balance?
Police officers are working vigorously to protect the safety of citizens and but there's
a relationship between citizens and the community and rights are respected and you don't have
those kinds of incidents.
It strikes me as a terribly difficult balance because in both cases, it's often the same
community that gets victimized, either victimized by crime or victimized by overzealous policing.
It's not easy obviously and you have to really set the right vision for what policing has
to be in the city.
Not many things in public life, if you don't have the community on your side, you will never
be successful and effective policing depends upon the legitimacy of the police in the eyes
of the community that they are sworn to protect.
And understanding that kind of basic fact, you work everything else around that, meaning
you've got to bring officers into communities and let them see the nuance and not just the
crime statistics.
You've got to bring the people into the academy so that they see officers in a very different
light.
You've got to put them in circumstances where they interact as human beings, not the cops
in the community.
Those are hard things to do but if you don't do those things and you don't do them consistently
forever, you're never going to bridge that divide.
And then inside of the police department itself, man oh man, it is a complicated, tough organization.
Cultural mores run deep and it is a constant struggle.
It's a bad and you've got to have a very strong leader at the top.
You have a new police chief now.
Yeah and you've got to make sure you empower that leader but I'm also hands on.
So as I say to them all the time, I don't have time or inclination to be the mayor just
at the police department.
But I'm going to be hands on it and I'm going to be a presence until I feel like we are
moved to a different chapter in the history of this police department and we are just
not there yet.
You have a new union leader there who is a contentious character, not necessarily
a light foot supporter.
I'd say exactly the opposite of that.
Yeah.
I mean how is that going to work?
You know look, I don't know him but I've had a lot of exposure to him.
He used to come to police board meetings when I was a police board president, sit in the
front row and everything about his demeanor was hateful.
I mean to just be blunt.
And he likes being provocative, he likes being controversial, he loves the media.
But I also know that he is now the leader of the largest police union in my city and
I have to figure out how we can forge some kind of working relationship if it's possible.
We've had some preliminary conversations.
I'm expecting that we will be getting together relatively soon.
I intend to give him the benefit of the doubt but I'm not going to cut and paste my values
to try to accommodate somebody whose values are very different than my own.
Police officers are important.
We need to support them and I'm going to continue to do that no matter who their leader is but
I hope that we can reach some common ground for the benefit of their, his members but
also for the benefit of the department in the city.
Mayor I so appreciate your time.
It's always good to talk with you.
There's probably hours and hours more that I could ask you about and want to ask you about.
Maybe we'll have a chance to do that again.
But right now you have a pandemic to deal with in a hundred other pressing issues.
So I just very much appreciate your time.
Thank you and thanks for the viewers and hanging with us.
Good luck.
Talk to you down the line.
Okay, thanks David.
Thank you for listening to The Axe Files.
Brought to you by the University of Chicago Institute of Politics and CNN Audio.
The executive producer of The Axe Files is Emily Stannitz.
The show is also produced by Miriam Annenberg, Samantha Neal and Alison Segal.
And special thanks to our partners at CNN, including Courtney Coop, Megan Marcus and
Ashley Lesk.
For more programming from the IOP, visit politics.uchicago.edu.

text: And now, from the University of Chicago Institute of Politics and CNN Audio, the axe files with your host, David Axelrod. Lori Lightfoot became mayor of Chicago. One year ago this week, her tenure began with a acrimonious teacher strike and it's ended with an epic pandemic. I sat down with her last week to talk about this baptism of fire, where she thinks the virus is going and how she plans to open up her city, plus her own remarkable story, her journey from a small town in Ohio, the granddaughter of a sharecropper, to become a prosecutor and ultimately a big city mayor. And we talked about her status as America's first gay woman of color to lead a major American city. And here's that conversation. Mayor, how are you? I'm doing well on you. Good. Good to see you. So next week, May 20th, one year in office, hell of a baptism you've had here. I mean, you couldn't have imagined when you took that oath of office in Millennium Park a year ago that this is how you'd be marking your first anniversary in office. How are you personally holding up? What is the emotional toll associated with having a lead a city through this kind of catastrophe? Well, I mean, as you might imagine, it ebbs and it flows. My personality is one where I don't get too high and I don't get too low. But certainly, you know, there are times when I feel like I've reached max in capacity. So I try to take some time for myself every day. Usually, it's early in the morning. I'm an early riser. So I just kind of take some time to kind of slowly move into the day, kind of set myself emotionally. And then I definitely do it every night before I go to bed. Sometimes I'm so tired I don't need to. I just fall asleep. There's an expression in the church that I grew up in about laying your burdens down. So what I try to do every night is just kind of let the burdens of the day to the side because they're going to be there the next day. I don't need to wrestle with them all night long. You know, easier said than done, of course. Yeah, that's a great quality. I need to take some lessons from you on that. I've never quite mastered that. But that is, it's important. How's your family doing you and your wife, Amy, have a 12-year-old Vivian? 12-year-olds are not necessarily all that keen on being penned up inside. How's she doing? She's doing fine. You know, she starts her day off every morning with a Zoom conference call from her teacher with her classmates. So when I'm running out the door in the morning, she's engaged in whatever the day's events are. And then I come home at night and she is discovered Fortnite. So that's like the daily obsession between her and varying groups of friends. But you know, it's hard. I mean, this would be a time where she'd be out running track. She's an athletic kid. She missed a lot of her basketball season because she had a broken leg. And so it was very looking forward to track and then COVID hits. So we tried to kind of get that as much exercise as we can. We're fortunate enough to have a yard, so we do that. But it's not the same. And it's not the same of being with your classmates every day and that kind of intimacy, that close proximity builds. But these are kids that have grown up in the digital age with all these devices. So it's probably a little bit different than when you and I were growing up. Speaking of the digital age, you've become quite the sensation online here. You're a viral sensation. You've been doing, you know, you've done all these videos about how to occupy yourself at home. You've done, I guess, parody of singing, you're baking. You've done a lot of some crazy things that have really caught on with people. How have you eased into the role of a viral star? Well, you know, I don't pay a lot of attention personally to social media, but I've got a great creative team. And when the memes started kind of popping up and having me all over Chicago, you know, we wanted to kind of bring home this message of staying home to save lives. We've done it in a parody of that, a take off around the senses. So you know, look, we're trying to meet people where they are. These memes caught fire. They kind of originated organically. And so we row the wave that somebody else really started. Now does Vivian catch you on TikTok in those places? So here's Vivian's reaction. She's obsessed with TikTok. And she's been trying to get Amy and I to do a TikTok with her. And I'm like, no, I'm not doing that. So when I came home that night and said, by the way, I just did my first TikTok. Of course, her reaction was, I can't believe you did it with somebody else and you did not do it with me. So such is such is a life of a 12 year old. Yes, I remember that. I remember that period. Listen, you know, I was a city hall reporter when Harold Washington got elected mayor of Chicago. You were the second elected African American mayor of Chicago. One of the striking things about this pandemic is just how brutal it has been on communities of color, those fault lines that you talked about during your campaign that you've talked about since they've been exposed in just a really tragic way. 75% of the cases in Chicago reported cases have been in the black and Hispanic communities. Deaths half the deaths in Chicago among the African American community, which is only 30% of the population. How do you process that? And what do we do about it? How do we begin to deal with the things that led up to this kind of tragedy? Well, it's an enormous challenge. And for me personally, processing those realities, it's been hard. When I first heard the data around African American, the impact on the African American community, I immediately went to thinking about my mother. Now, she doesn't live here, but she's 91 years old and has underlying conditions. I'm the youngest of four and my siblings are old enough that they fit into the demographic of over 60 and several have underlying conditions. So it's hard not to feel that personally. But what I also knew is it was really important for us not to just drop this information on people, but as you said, to really come up with some concrete ways in which we as a city and then embracing our community partners could really respond to this because there is a need. I mean, it's not a secret that there are healthcare disparities in our city. It's not a secret that way too many people live in poverty and that black and brown communities are have much higher rate of these underlying conditions that we now know are the death male for COVID. You know, 93% or higher than that of the people who have died had underlying medical conditions like diabetes, heart disease, upper respiratory disease. So that is a haunting statistic. And I think the way that I process it is to feel like we are doing something to address that we are empowering people by giving them information, that we are connecting them up to healthcare systems, whether it's a family doctor or a federally qualified health center, that we are being as responsive and close to the ground in these neighborhoods that are so dramatically affected and being empathetic and making sure that we are doing everything we can to flood those areas with resources. You know what worries me is that when this goes, when this lifts, whenever that is and God knows we all hope that it's sooner rather than later, that those same conditions will exist that made these communities vulnerable. You've talked a lot about and you've laid out ambitious visions and plans for trying to eradicate poverty in the city and getting into these neighborhoods that are most vulnerable right now. It's also true that this virus is also eating away at cities' revenues, creating extraordinary budget concerns for you. And you already had a situation where you have pension obligations that are growing, that you're now responsible to deal with. The history of this is that when these things happen, the first communities that suffer are the communities that always suffer, the poor, the vulnerable. How do you launch a war on poverty when you are in such a financial bind? I think we have no choice. I gave a speech last December to the Economic Club and then I spoke with them yesterday. At the time in December, I said that we can't be a great global city unless we focus on inclusive growth, that we see the city as being something larger and bigger than the central business district. I repeated that message yesterday. While yes, these problems are tough. They were daunting before COVID. They're even more daunting now. But the thing that we've been doing all along and I've really pushed my staff is to not build temporary staff scaffolding. We don't want to put a band-aid on a gaping wound. We're not going to solve the problem in this entirely in the months and the arc of this virus, but we've got to accelerate the plans that we previously had and start to address these long-standing problems now. And that's precisely what we've done. And then thinking about the budget and the impact of this is significant. There's no question about it. I am grateful for the money that we've gotten from the federal government and I've got to give credit to the Democrats in the House because we would have gotten a lot less, but but for the leadership of the speaker and others to insist upon direct aid to cities like Chicago, I'm hopeful that they'll win more because the CARES Act money that we received already is constrained. We can only use that for COVID responses. And believe me, we're going to use it because we're going to need it, but we need more support, but we have to continue to speak our values even in these tough economic times. If we shed and move away from those communities that are most in need right now, we're giving up on a huge swass of Chicago. We're saying that Chicago is not going to be 2.7 million. It's barely going to be 2 million because people will leave. Right. And most of the people who are leaving are people of color, poor people. Chicago is really one of the only world-class cities where you see population declining, and that's where the decline is happening. That's exactly right. And if we give up and say we can't afford to do the kind of investments that we can't afford to have inclusive economic growth, we're giving up on a vision of Chicago. That I just think is critically important to define who we are now and in the future. I totally get that. I just don't know where the money comes from. Some of it may be from the voluntary contributions of those people you were talking to yesterday at the Economic Club. And the question is, how much are they willing to put their money where your mouth is and try and deal with some of these problems? Because it seems impossible that you can get the money you need simply from taxpayers' property taxes are high already. Yeah, there's no question. We never envisioned that we were going to have the city of Chicago go at a long strategy. We have to have partnership. Both partnerships in helping us think about what the policy prescriptions should be. But of course, partnerships in terms of the money and the revenue. And we've been very fortunate already when we announced, for example, our Invest Southwest program, which is investing in exactly the same neighborhoods. We put up money from the city, but we were joined by BMO Harris Bank. They put up $20 million. And then we got another 10 from Starbucks and on and on. We can't do these things and move the needle in an meaningful way without partnerships of the philanthropy community, but also the business community. I've always thought that to deal with the massive problems that go into the situation that these communities are in would require a massive response from the philanthropic community, the corporate community. Governments simply doesn't have the resources to do everything that's necessary. Listen, in addition to making people laugh, you've also scared the hell out of people. And you've been out on the street at times when there were people who were defying the stay-at-home order, including young people partying. And you've been very blunt about your feelings about that. Now we're reaching something of a breaking point with some people who've been inside for a long time. It was a predictable that as time went on, people would be impatient. A lot of people out of work. A lot of small businesses. I know you've spoken to that at the breaking point. And yet we're not nearly done. The virus is still out there. There's no vaccine yet. So are you worried about that? Are you worried about just more and more defiance, more and more resistance, lack of political will to do what's necessary? And then finding us, as Dr. Bright, who testified before Congress today, warned, finding us back in a situation that is as bad or worse a few months from now. And our city is really built around having fun, recreational and entertainment options. That's one of the things that makes Chicago special. And as the weather gets warm and while we didn't have the terrible winter that we've had in many years, your body and I think your mind has an expectation that when a days get longer, when the sun is shining, it's time to be outside. It's time to reconvene with people that you may not have seen during the winter months. So we have to manage that and deal with that reality. And so I've been reading a lot, as has our Department of Public Health, about how we can safely convene, particularly outside. And I think there's opportunities for us to not move away from the diligence about social distancing. That's going to be what that's, I think, for the foreseeable future. You know, all the kind of things that we would ordinarily do inside, some of what we do outside. I think there are ways, given the great venues that we have, to bring those experiences outside. I do think that that is possible. President has been sort of encouraging that spirit of resistance lately. I know you've had an interesting relationship. He called you when you were elected. There's no doubt that he's making it harder. But he's making it harder mostly because the federal response has been so halting. And it's been that way really from the very beginning of this pandemic. Look, my ambition is to get our kids back in school this fall. And we got to address it because it's a larger problem. But what I also know is I think about the little kids when my daughter was a three-year-old going to pre-K. The social-emotional learning that happens in that environment, when they're away from their parents for the first time and they're with other kids and they're with their teachers and they start to learn the love of learning, structure of school, being able to play safely. All of those things are critically important, particularly for our youngest kids, and that doesn't happen when you're seeing your teacher for the very first time ever on a digital screen. So for those kids, when I think about it, it's really important that we get them back in school. Now again, we're not going to do it in a way that puts anybody at risk. We're not going to do it in a way that isn't consultative with the entire ecosystem of those school environment. The principals, the teachers, the aides, the lunchroom staff, all of those people are important for the lifeblood of a school. And we've got to do it in a way that we keep them safe and we keep the children safe. And we've got to explore every opportunity because of how important it is for those youngest of children to find that connection with their beloved teachers. So ambition but no guarantee, basically. We can't... There's no way anybody who can guarantee what's going to happen in the fall is making it up. There's no guarantee they can be given. So you are a big sports fan. You, I ask you that question as the former star point guard for Washington High School in Masaland, Ohio. No, I think a lot about that as I talk to health care workers, as I talk to the unions who are concerned, and also just the folks that run these facilities. I know from my mom's experience, and I hope to, I hope to God is a million times better than it was when she was out there. They are in the front lines. They don't get the training that they should get. And they don't oftentimes get the kind of equipment to keep them safe. I think it's a different world now, and part of that is because many of these workers are unionized. Now, we also know from the archivist virus that congregate settings are places where this virus just spreads like wildfire. That's why our Department of Public Health has been very active and engaged with senior centers, nursing homes, and other settings like that. Absolutely. Your folks, your father Elijah, he was the son of a sharecropper. Both your parents grew up in the segregated South, moved north. He had hearing loss as a result of men and chitis. And in some ways, I think he never recovered from growing up in the South. And then adding proverbial insult to injury, growing up, not really having an opportunity to live out his life's ambitions, getting sick, sir early on in his early 20s, losing his hearing. So being a black man with a high school education and then a profound disability, just really shaped and confined his world. My dad had a great sense of humor. He had loved life, but he had to work hard every single day. That's when my dad in and Sundays were really the only day where I got to see my dad for the entirety of the day because his work life was six days a week. Do you, how much did his struggle forge your determination to do what you've done with your own life? It definitely deeply influenced me to see my father worrying every single day about basics, the utilities, its car payment, rent. And then we were fortunate enough to move into a house and have a mortgage. I never wanted to struggle in the way that he did. And I didn't know where my life would take me, but I knew that I wanted to have some economic freedom at least so that I could help them, which I have done, but also be able to help myself and have some freedom. You know, when you have to worry every single day about staying in your house, about somebody coming and taking your car, about just being able to get through the day financially, that takes a toll on you. And that was the story of my parents' life, for much of their married life together. You mentioned that they were able to buy a house. They moved to, yours was a segregated town like most towns were in the day's small industrial kind of town, about 400 miles from Chicago in Ohio. But they moved to a predominantly white neighborhood and they did that intentionally. Talk to me about that and how did that impact on you? Because you must have been very much in a minority in some of your school classes and in your neighborhood and so on. How did that shape your thinking and your life? I think that, look, the town was incredibly segregated. And at the time that my parents were making a decision about where they could buy, they wanted to buy, well, we lived in this area for the entirety of my life. We moved probably into a house that was about four or five blocks away from our rental home. But they wanted us to be able to stay close to the friends that we had known our entire growing up years and to be in the same school system that we had known. So my parents really sacrificed everything for us as children. And really, the way in which they lived their lives was about what was best for us. And so that really drove the decisions. And you're right, when I have a brother who was six years older than me, when he left my elementary school for the entirety of the rest of the time that I was there, which is about five years from first grade to sixth grade, I was literally the only black kid in my school. And in my town, it was black and white. They were tiny, tiny, maybe two or three families that were Latinx. So yeah, I grew up for most of my schooling until I got to high school as being either the only or a small handful of black students in an otherwise white school. And how did that feel? I mean, was there, did you feel as an outsider there? I mean, yes and no, right? I grew up in the late sixties and early seventies. You know, while it was Ohio, not Alabama, you know, segregation was still an issue, blatant on the table, racial discrimination was still a thing. There were certain things I couldn't do. And I knew places I couldn't go because I was black that my classmates were going to. And yeah, I mean, I definitely struggled with my identity as a black person for a long time growing up in very white environment. I think the thing that was helpful to me is I was a good student. So I was always one of the best in my class, best in the school. That made a huge difference. And then when I was in seventh or eighth grade, my mother got appointed to the local school board and then she ran for election and then through the rest of my time in school, she was a member of the school board. So frankly, that helped a lot. But when I got to high school and then we were, it was one public high school in my town, I started then seeing black kids, some of them who I knew from church, that a lot of whom I didn't know. And it was a struggle because I stood out like a sore thumb. I talk like I talk now. I didn't, as they said, talk black. And there was a lot of you think you're better. You know, a lot of the petty crap that happens in junior high and really in high school, I experienced a lot of that. But I had my mother in my ear constantly, literally and but also figuratively telling me to push myself to do the best I could, not let people bring me down. I mean, that was kind of a daily mantra in my household. But yeah, it was tough. It was absolutely tough. One of your siblings, your brother Brian, took a different path and not a happy one. It was really hard. It was really hard on us as a family. I told this story. Yeah, for some people, and my brother was definitely one of them, the street life is almost like an narcotic in and of itself. It is incredibly alluring. And my brother started kind of going in a different direction when he was a teenager. I can remember when he was probably 13, 14 years old, hanging out with a group of guys, some of whom beat him to jail, some of whom died. He had a friend who was killed in a robbery when he was a teenager. But my brother was determined to really take a very different course. And he ended up spending most of his adult life locked up. The last was 17 years in federal prison. He got out now probably five or six years ago. He lives now in the same town that my mother lives in. But when you're a 60-something year old man and you've never really had a legitimate job in your life, and you've spent the entirety of your growing up years on the inside, that does something to you. Are you in touch? Kind of. We go through ebbs and flows. He came and he was here for the inauguration. Our context is kind of slowly diminished over time. My brother struggles with addiction still. That's just not realistic when you've been a guy on the streets for most of your life. And so the hustle is very still very alluring to him. And now a word from our sponsors. That I was going to be loyal to the constitution and of all the laws because my brother was a fugitive from justice. Yeah, and of course like with seeing my father and the men in the eyes of really hard working men of color. I of course thought about my brother when I was prosecuting Chicago Street gang members. And we had a range of interesting conversations with the young men that were both cooperators but also the young men that we were arranging plea deals for. Some of the men that I prosecuted here on the streets in Chicago ended up in a facility in Myelin, Michigan when my brother was there at the same time. So there's nothing about the incarceration of human beings that is easy, that is simple, even the people that are the most dangerous and that are psychopathic and some of them are. That's somebody's kid. Yeah. That's somebody's sibling. And you can never forget that. And I certainly never forgot that when I was a prosecutor. You went to the University of Michigan and then you came here to the University of Chicago Law School. There were very few people of color. But interestingly, there were actually a lot of gays in the law school. And that really helped me. In my experience in 30 plus years of living in the city, the tolerance for it is still really great. I'm probably, you probably didn't read the indictment of Ed Burke, but I did. Ed Burke, the senior alderman in the city council, longtime power in the city in the democratic organization, go ahead. He stays there for five or ten minutes, clearly got a set of instructions and then dutifully went and on some trumped up bases, shut down a building site because from the Ed Burke's perspective, the guy hadn't come across with the money. He hadn't hired him to do the legal work. And so while this person probably didn't know there was a criminal conspiracy going on, the obedience to this power and doing something that didn't comport at all, you know, with a building called what is actual true job wise, but the willingness to be a party to it because a powerful alderman and a staff had commanded it, we have just tolerated corruption way too long. And you know, gang violence is really complicated, but in short strokes, it comes down in my mind to poverty.
